key_points: Edward Osborne Wilson was celebrated as one of the greatest biologists of the 20th century, specializing in ants and making significant contributions to ecology and evolution.
Wilson's early love for nature led him to describe hundreds of new species and study social insect behavior, changing our understanding of communication and behavior.
He experienced conflict in his career, notably clashing with James Watson over the value of classical biology versus molecular biology at Harvard.
Wilson pioneered sociobiology, linking behavior to evolutionary and genetic factors, sparking widespread debate and controversy.
His work was met with fierce opposition, particularly from figures like Richard Lewontin and Steve Gould, and he was physically attacked during a presentation.
Wilson sought to address controversy with his book "On Human Nature," which won a Pulitzer Prize and helped quiet some criticism.
Despite a difficult childhood and loss of vision in one eye, Wilson's passion for exploring nature persisted, leading him to major scientific discoveries.
He distanced himself from fundamentalist Protestantism after discovering evolutionary theory, and while not an atheist, he expressed skepticism about organized religion.
Wilson's book "The Creation" aimed at bridging the gap between scientists and Christians for environmental conservation.
His legacy includes efforts to preserve biodiversity, exemplified by his proposal for the "Encyclopedia of Life," aiming to document every species.
